fishergw.taylorf2 package¶

Submodules¶

fishergw.taylorf2.fisher module¶

class fishergw.taylorf2.fisher.Fisher(signal, integration_method=<function simps>, asd_name=None, detector=None, keys=None, logscale_keys=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

An object to load the power spectral density (PSD) and compute the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) and the Fisher matrix elements of a gravitational wave signal. The SNR and the Fisher matrix are averaged over orientation and inclination angles.

Attributes:

signal (TaylorF2) – A TaylorF2 waveform instance.

integration_method (scipy.integrate) – An integration method from the scipy.integrate subpackage.

psd (scipy.interpolate.interp1d) – Interpolant of the PSD. An instance of scipy.interpolate.interp1d.

fmin (float) – If asd_name is provided, fmin is the corresponding minimum frequency. Otherwise, fmin = None.

fmax (float) – If asd_name is provided, fmax is the corresponding maximum frequency. Otherwise, fmax = None.

Qavg (float) – Angle-averaging factor \(Q\). When load_asd() is called, the PSD is divided by \(Q^2\) to ensure that the SNR and the Fisher matrix elements are angle-averaged.

keys (list) – Independent variables w.r.t. which the Fisher matrix is evaluated.

_detectors_ (dict) – Dictionary mapping built-in detectors to their asd_name and angle-averaging factor \(Q\). Built-in detectors are Advanced Ligo ('aligo'), Cosmic Explorer ('ce'), Einstein Telescope ('etd') and LISA ('lisa'). The following conventions hold for \(Q\):

'aligo' and 'ce' are mapped to the factor \(Q=2/5\) for a two-armed 90-degrees detector (see, e.g., Eq. (7.177) in [1]);

'etd' is mapped to \(Q=2/5*\sqrt{3/2}\), the additional factor \(\sqrt{3/2}\) coming from the fact that ET is a three-armed 60-degrees detector with two channels (see Eq. (4) in https://arxiv.org/abs/1012.0908);

'lisa' is mapped to \(Q=2/\sqrt{5}\). This only accounts for averaging over the inclination angle, because the LISA sensitivity curve is already averaged over orientation and detector channels (see Eq.s (2,8-9) in https://arxiv.org/abs/1803.01944).

References:

[1] Maggiore, Michele. Gravitational waves: Volume 1: Theory and experiments. Vol. 1. Oxford university press, 2008.

__init__(signal, integration_method=<function simps>, asd_name=None, detector=None, keys=None, logscale_keys=None)[source]¶
Parameters

  • signal (TaylorF2) – A TaylorF2 waveform instance

  • integration_method (scipy.integrate object, default= scipy.integrate.simps) – The integration method to compute the SNR and the Fisher matrix elements.

  • asd_name (filepath or None, optional) – The path to a text file with the tabulated ASD. If None, the ASD defaults to 1.0. If detector is not None, asd_name is read from the _detectors_ internal dictionary

  • detector (str or None, optional) – If not None, must be one of ['aligo','ce','etd','lisa'].

  • keys (list of str or None) – Independent variables w.r.t. which the Fisher matrix is evaluated. If None, defaults to self.signal.keys.

  • logscale_keys (list or None, optional) – Subset of keys to be converted in log scale when computing the Fisher. Default: None.

correlation_matrix(fm, svd=False)[source]¶

Returns the correlation matrix. If svd, the Fisher matrix is inverted with a singular value decomposition.

Parameters

fm (numpy.array, shape (len(self.keys),len(self.keys))) – The Fisher matrix.

Return type

numpy.array, shape (len(self.keys),len(self.keys))

covariance_matrix(fm, svd=False)[source]¶

Returns the covariance matrix. If svd, the Fisher matrix is inverted with a singular value decomposition.

Parameters

fm (numpy.array, shape (len(self.keys),len(self.keys))) – The Fisher matrix.

Return type

numpy.array, shape (len(self.keys),len(self.keys))

fisher_matrix(fmin=None, fmax=None, nbins=100000.0, priors=None, logspace=False)[source]¶

Returns the Fisher matrix. Gaussian priors can be specified based on https://arxiv.org/abs/gr-qc/9502040.

Parameters

  • fmin (float or None, optional) – Minimum frequency. If None, defaults to the minimum frequency set by the provided PSD file.

  • fmax (float or None, optional) – Maximum frequency. If None, defaults to the maximum frequency set by the provided PSD file.

  • nbins (float) – Binning of the integration domain. Defaults to 1e5.

  • priors (dict or None) – Dictionary mapping each variable name with the standard deviation of its Gaussian prior. Defaults to None.

  • logspace (Bool) – If True, integrations are performed in logspace over frequencies. Default: False.

Return type

numpy.array, shape (len(keys),len(keys))

static invert_matrix(matrix, svd=False, tol=1e-06)[source]¶

Returns the inverse of the a matrix.

Parameters

  • matrix (numpy.array) – The input matrix.

  • svd – If True a singular value decomposition is applied and principal directions with singular values smaller than tol are discarded. Default: False.

  • svd – bool, optional

  • tol (float) – Directions with singular values smaller than tol are discarded when inverting the matrix. Default: 1e-6.

Return type

numpy.array

load_psd(asd_name, Qavg=1.0, logspace=False)[source]¶

Loads the PSD from a text file. Initializes the attributes psd, fmin, fmax and Qavg.

Parameters

  • asd_name (str) – name of the text file containing the ASD table. The file will be first looked into the fishergw/detector/ folder, then into the fishergw/detector/unofficial_asd/ folder. Otherwise, asd_name must be the full path of the text file.

  • Qavg (float) – Value of the angle-averaging factor. See the description in the Fisher attributes. Default: 1.

  • logspace (bool) – If True, the ASD is interpolated in logspace along the y-axis. Default: False.

sample(covariance_matrix, nsamples=10000.0, keys=None)[source]¶

Returns sampled parameters from the posterior distribution given by the covariance matrix.

Parameters

  • covariance_matrix (numpy.array, shape (len(keys),len(keys))) – The covariance matrix determining the likelihood.

  • nsamples (float) – Number of samples to draw. Defaults: 1e4.

  • keys (list.) – List of variable names to sample. It must be a subset of self.keys. If None, defaults to self.keys.

Return type

numpy.array, shape (len(keys),nsamples).

sigma1d(fm, svd=False)[source]¶

Returns the standard deviations of the 1D marginalized posteriors. If svd, the Fisher matrix is inverted with a singular value decomposition.

Parameters

fm (numpy.array, shape (len(self.keys),len(self.keys))) – The Fisher matrix.

Returns

Dictionary mapping self.keys to the corresponding standard deviations.

Return type

dict

snr(fmin=None, fmax=None, nbins=100000.0, logspace=False)[source]¶

Returns the SNR of the signal.

Parameters

  • fmin (float or None, optional) – Minimum frequency. If None, defaults to the minimum frequency set by the provided ASD file.

  • fmax (float or None, optional) – Maximum frequency. If None, defaults to the maximum frequency set by the provided ASD file.

  • nbins (float) – Binning of the integration domain. Defaults to 1e5.

  • logspace (bool) – If True, integration is performed in logspace over frequencies. Default: False.

Return type

float

fishergw.taylorf2.waveform module¶

class fishergw.taylorf2.waveform.CompactObject(mass, spin, Lamda=0.0, kappa=1.0, radius=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

A class to define an isolated compact object.

Attributes:

mass (float) – Mass [\(M_\odot\)].

spin (float) – Dimensionless spin.

Lamda (float) – Dimensionless tidal deformability.

kappa (float) – Dimensionless spin-induced quadrupole moment.

radius (float) – Radius [m].

__init__(mass, spin, Lamda=0.0, kappa=1.0, radius=None)[source]¶
Parameters

  • mass (float) – Mass [\(M_\odot\)].

  • spin (float) – Dimensionless spin.

  • Lamda (float, default=0.0) – Tidal deformability. Defaults to the black hole value.

  • kappa (float, default=1.0) – Dimensionless spin-induced quadrupole moment. Defaults to the black hole value.

  • radius (float) – Radius of the compact object [m]. If None, defaults to the ISCO radius of a Schwarzschild black hole with the same mass.

class fishergw.taylorf2.waveform.TaylorF2(obj1, obj2, d_L=100.0, t_c=0.0, phi_c=0.0, redshift=False, PN_phase=3.5)[source]¶

Bases: object

TaylorF2 frequency-domain template for the inspiral waveform from a binary coalescence.

Attributes:

d_L (float) – Luminosity distance [Mpc].

t_c (float) – Time of coalescence.

phi_c (float) – Phase of coalescence.

M (float) – Total mass in the detector frame [m].

Note

In TaylorF2, masses are transformed in units of meters as \(MG/c^2\).

kappa_s (float) – Symmetrized quadrupole moment.

kappa_a (float) – Antisymmetrized quadrupole moment.

eta (float) – Symmetric mass ratio.

M_c (float) – Chirp mass in the detector frame [m].

q (float) – Mass ratio obj1.mass/obj2.mass.

chi_s (float) – Symmetrized dimensionless spin.

chi_a (float) – Antisymmetrized dimensionless spin.

Lamda_T (float) – Dimensionless tidal deformability of the binary, according to Eq. (14) in https://arxiv.org/abs/1410.8866.

delta_Lambda (float) – Auxiliary tidal parameter, according to Eq. (15) in https://arxiv.org/abs/1410.8866.

keys (list)– Independent variables w.r.t. which the Fisher matrix is evaluated. Default ['t_c','phi_c','M_c','eta','chi_s','chi_a','Lamda_T','delta_Lamda'].

Note

Because the TaylorF2 phase is linear in t_c and phi_c, the actual values of t_c and phi_c are irrelevant to the computation of the Fisher matrix and can be left to their default.

Note

TaylorF2 assumes that the normalization of Eq. (7.177) in [1], without the angular factor Q. The angular factor is taken into account when loading the sensitivity curve by Fisher instances.

References:

[1] Maggiore, Michele. Gravitational waves: Volume 1: Theory and experiments. Vol. 1. Oxford university press, 2008.

__call__(f)[source]¶

Returns the value of the strain at a given frequency.

Parameters

f (float) – Frequency [Hz].

Return type

complex

__init__(obj1, obj2, d_L=100.0, t_c=0.0, phi_c=0.0, redshift=False, PN_phase=3.5)[source]¶
Parameters

  • obj1 (CompactObject) – Primary compact object in the binary.

  • obj2 (CompactObject) – Secondary compact object in the binary.

  • d_L (float) – Luminosity distance [Mpc]. Default: 100.

  • t_c (float) – Time of coalescence. Defaut: 0.

  • phi_c (float) – Phase of coalescence. Default: 0.

  • redshift (bool, optional) – If True, the masses are redshifted, otherwise the redshift is neglected. Default: False.

  • PN_phase (half-integer.) – The PN order up to wich the waveform phase is expanded. It does not include tidal terms at 5PN and 6PN orders. They are always nonvanishing whenever obj1 or obj2 have a nonvanishing tidal parameter. Default: 3.5.

isco(mode='static')[source]¶

Returns the ISCO frequency of the system.

Parameters

mode (str) – If static, neglects the contribution of the indivudal spins. If ‘Kerr’, uses the Kerr ISCO with gravitational self-force corrections and test-particle spin corrections from https://arxiv.org/abs/1010.2553. Currently, these are the only supported options. Default: static.

Return type

float

start_frequency_from_obs_time(obs_time=1.0)[source]¶

Returns the starting frequency given the osbervational time, as per Eq. (2.15) in https://arxiv.org/abs/gr-qc/0411129v2.

Parameters

obs_time (float) – The observational time [yr]. Default: 1.

Return type

float

fishergw.taylorf2.waveform.delta_lamda(eta, l1, l2)[source]¶

Returns the tidal parameter of a binary compact object from Eq.(15) in https://arxiv.org/pdf/1410.8866.pdf.

Parameters

  • eta (float) – symmetric mass ratio of the binary.

  • l1 (float) – dimensionless tidal parameter of the primary component.

  • l2 (float) – dimensionless tidal parameter of the secondary component.

Return type

float

fishergw.taylorf2.waveform.lamda_tilde(eta, l1, l2)[source]¶

Returns the tidal parameter of a binary compact object from Eq.(14) in https://arxiv.org/pdf/1410.8866.pdf.

Parameters

  • eta (float) – symmetric mass ratio of the binary.

  • l1 (float) – dimensionless tidal parameter of the primary component.

  • l2 (float) – dimensionless tidal parameter of the secondary component.

Return type

float
